Question.Name: Scale
Question.Description: This question uses a diagram to test the student's knowledge of categorization for various astronomical objects (Jupiter, Virgo Supercluster, Polaris, Andromeda Galaxy, Comet Halley, and the Orion Nebula). The student is given the name of the object and is asked to place it in one of three hierarchical categories: Solar System, Milky Way, or Universe.

Question.Name: Increasing Distance
Question.Description: This question asks the students to place a list of astronomical objects (various planets, stars, galaxies, and superclusters) in order of increasing distance from Earth.

Question.Name: Scientific Notation
Question.Description: This question asks the student to convert units of measure to and from scientific notation, as well as to converts metric prefixes to their corresponding numbers in scientific notation.

Question.Name: Calculation in Scientific Notation
Question.Description: This question asks students to calculate various distances to various objects based on various units of measure (solar radii, astronomical units, galactic radii), as well as to use the number of stars in the galaxy as a basis to estimate the number of stars in the universe, in order that the student becomes familiar with basic mathematics using scientific notation.

Question.Name: Special Units
Question.Description: This question asks the student to determine the most logical unit of measure for various distances (to the nearest state, planet, star, etc.), using light years, parsecs, astronomical units, meters, and all metric prefix permutations of these.

Question.Name: Dimensional Analysis
Question.Description: This questions asks the students to extrapolate various dimensions of astronomical bodies based on their radii, volumes, etc (determine the radius of Jupiter based on how many Earths fit inside, the cross-section of a particle in Saturn's ring given the radius, and the surface area of such a particle given the radius).

Question.Name: Light-Travel Time
Question.Description: This question involves the speed of light as related to time and distance. The student is asked either to determine a distance in light years using a hypothetical speed of light, determine a distance a photon travels during a given period of time, or determine how much time it takes for a photon to travel a certain distance.

Question.Name: Look-Back Time
Question.Description: This question asks the student to determine how long it would take light emitted from a given object (a galaxy or a supernova) to reach an observer on Earth, also known as the look-back time for that object. The students are also asked to give the date an event might have occurred, as well as a projected date of knowledge of the event for an observer on Earth.

Question.Name: Graph: Circumference
Question.Description: This question tests the student's ability to put an equation into graph-form, in this case using radius vs. circumference.

Question.Name: Earth Rotations
Question.Description: This question asks the student to differentiate between rotation and revolution. The student is to determine how many rotations the Earth has gone through in a given number of revolutions around the sun.

Question.Name: Precision/Accuracy
Question.Description: The student is shown four groups of arrows in a target, and is asked to differentiate between the precision of the archer's shooting as and the archer's accuracy.

Question.Name: Common Densities
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify the largest and smallest values in a list of densities of common substances.

Question.Name: Density and Volume
Question.Description: Student understanding of the relationship between density, mass, and volume is probed.

Question.Name: Trash Density
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify the appropriate graph of density vs time for the contents of a trash compactor.

Question.Name: Density of Combined Object
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify what happens to the density when identical objects are combined.

Question.Name: Properties of Density
Question.Description: Students are asked what happens to the density when an object with a uniform density is cut in pieces.

Question.Name: Spin Lookback Time
Question.Description: Occurrences in the Sci-Fi book Spin are used to motivate a discussion of light travel time.

Question.Name: Star on North Point
Question.Description: The student is told a star is at the north point and is asked to determine where the star will be located in the sky 6 or 12 hours later. This tests the student's knowledge of the apparent nightly motion of stars through the sky due to the Earth's rotation.

Question.Name: From Horizon to Zenith
Question.Description: The student is given the positions of three stars as they begin to rise above the horizon and the current latitude of the observer's location, and is asked to determine which will eventually reach the zenith.

Question.Name: Seasonal Sky Analogy
Question.Description: The student is shown four diagrams of students pointing toward or away from the sun, and is asked to determine which diagram accurately depicts the reason different constellations are visible during different seasons (specifically summer and winter).

Question.Name: Apparent Motion of the Sun
Question.Description: Given the actual motion of the sun, the student is asked about the apparent motion of Earth.

Question.Name: Location of Planets
Question.Description: The student is given a bit of historical information about the Greeks' discovery of the planets, and is asked to determine which given diagram depicts where the Greeks could (and can) look in the sky to locate these 'wanderers'.

Question.Name: Planet Positions
Question.Description: The student is shown the positions of different planets (Jupiter and Venus) in the sky as they are rising or setting in two different locations (Boulder and Knoxville) and is asked to determine where they would be located in 6 hours due to the rotation of the Earth.

Question.Name: Aristarchus
Question.Description: Aristarchus' experiment is shown, wherein he measured the Earth-Sun distance in terms of the Earth-Moon distance, and the student is asked why he chose to use the third-quarter moon to obtain this distance, and why his resulting distance was so much smaller than the current value.

Question.Name: Angular Diameter Mobile
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify the largest and smallest angular diameters for various balls at various distances.

Question.Name: Angular Diameter of a Balloon
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify how angular diameters changes as the size and distances of objects change.

Question.Name: Moon Stacking
Question.Description: Students are asked about the angular diameter of the moon and hypothetical adjacent moons.

Question.Name: Eratothenes
Question.Description: Eratosthenes' experiment is diagrammed where the circumference of Earth was estimated in ancient Greece. Students are asked to work with the logic related to how far the sun was off of the zenith and the separation of the two locations.

Question.Name: Eratosthenes Analogies
Question.Description: Real world situations are presented which use the same mathematical logic as Eratosthenes' Experiment.

Question.Name: Key Mound
Question.Description: Key mounds (azimuth markers) are used to probem student understanding of the azimuth values of the rising and setting sun on the solstices.

Question.Name: Heliacal Rising
Question.Description: The student is given the definition of the heliacal rising (based on an ancient Egyptian calendar) and is asked to determine when the reappearance of Sirius would occur in relation to the sun's rising or setting.n

Question.Name: Morning/Evening Star
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify the morning stars and evening stars from top-down views of our solar system.

Question.Name: Daylight
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation involving a 2-dimension view of the globe, where dark and light areas represent daylight and night respectively, and is asked to determine whether or not the motions showing the changes between daylight and night on various parts of the globe is realistic or not based on the Earth's tilted rotation.

Question.Name: Diurnal Warmup
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a star moving through the sky on a supposedly diurnal path at a certain location, and the student is asked to determine if the animation is realistic.

Question.Name: Incorrect Sun Animation
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a supposed animation of the sun's motion and asked "what is wrong with this animation?". We have shown the yearly motion along the ecliptic instead of a daily motion at constant declination.

Question.Name: Best Day
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine what months (and thus seasons) would be best for different activities (sledding or going to the beach) at different locations around the world (Germany, Chile, Canada, and New Zealand), representing both the northern and southern hemispheres.

Question.Name: Change to Earth Seasons
Question.Description: The student is given both the eccentricity of Earth's orbit and its obliquity (tilt), and is asked to determine how the seasons would change with various changes in those two values.

Question.Name: Seasons Contributor(s)
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine what contributes to the seasons on Earth (altitude of sun's rays, sun's time spent above horizon, proximity of Earth in relation to the sun, or a combination of the above).

Question.Name: No Orbital Tilt
Question.Description: Asks the student to identify the manifestations of Earth having no orbital tilt.

Question.Name: Tropics and Tilt
Question.Description: Student is asked to identify the locations of various parallels of latitude for a planet with a different obliquity than Earth.

Question.Name: Terrestrial Coordinates 1
Question.Description: The student is given various latitude and longitude coordinates for a terrestrial city and is asked to determine on which continent the city is located.

Question.Name: Terrestrial Coordinates 2
Question.Description: The student is given a terrestrial location and is asked to determine which lines of latitude and longitude would intersect at this place

Question.Name: RA-Dec Locations
Question.Description: The student is given a list of right ascension and declination values, and is asked to determine which set would be closest to a given location on the celestial sphere (the celestial poles, equinoxes, celestial equator, or ecliptic).

Question.Name: Date of Sun on the Ecliptic
Question.Description: The student is shown a flat graph of the sun's path through the sky across the year, and is asked to determine based on the sun's location on the ecliptic line on the graph what day it is (the equinoxes or solstices).

Question.Name: Sun on the Ecliptic
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of the sun moving along the ecliptic a certain distance on a flat graph and is asked to determine what range of dates is represented by this motion (between solstices and equinoxes).

Question.Name: Sun at the Zenith
Question.Description: The student is shown a flat graph of the sun's path through the sky across the year, and is asked to determine based on the sun's location on the ecliptic line on the graph at what latitude an observer would see the sun pass through the zenith.

Question.Name: Sun's Rays
Question.Description: The student is shown an image of the sun's rays landing on Earth at different angles and is asked to determine the calendar date thus represented.

Question.Name: Sun Movement
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine where the sun is on the day the question is viewed and in which direction it will move over the ensuing months, based on the ecliptic's angle with the Earth's axis.

Question.Name: Sun at Zenith Frequency
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of the sun moving through the seasons on a flat map of Earth and is asked to determine the frequency with which the sun will appear at the zenith for various latitudes (the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, the Artic and Antarctic Circles, and values in between).

Question.Name: Effects of Tilt
Question.Description: Student is asked to identify the appropriate effects for a given obliquity and given latitude.

Question.Name: Meaning of Tropics
Question.Description: Student is describe the visability of the sun from various locations on Earth relative to the tropics.

Question.Name: Percent of Stars Visible
Question.Description: Student is asked to identify the percentage of stars on the celestial sphere that are visible throughout the year from various locations.

Question.Name: Az-Alt Locations
Question.Description: The student is shown asked to choose from a list of altitude and azimuth coordinates that best describe the location of a given point on the student's horizon system (north point, celestial pole, zenith, meridional intersection, west point).

Question.Name: Azimuth and Altitude
Question.Description: The student is shown a picture of Memorial Stadium in Lincoln (which runs north to south and is viewed in the picture facing west) and is asked, assuming a position at the center of the field, the altitude and azimuth of various objects in or around the field (a tuba, the goalposts, a large N, or a blimp).

Question.Name: Boat Azimuth
Question.Description: Student is asked to identify the azimuth of enemy combatants to be targeted.

Question.Name: Altitude of the Pole
Question.Description: The student is to determine what the altitude of either the north or south celestial poles would be from the north or south point at different latitudes.

Question.Name: Declination Ranges
Question.Description: The student is given various locations at various latitudes in the northern and southern hemisphere and the declination of various stars, and is asked to determine whether the star would be circumpolar, rise and set, or never rise at that latitude.

Question.Name: Meridional Altitude for the Sun
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the meridional altitude of the sun at various times of the year (the solstices or equinoxes) at different latitudes.

Question.Name: Meridional Altitude for Stars
Question.Description: The student is given various stars' declinations and is asked to determine what would be their meridional altitudes at various latitudes.

Question.Name: Star Trails
Question.Description: The student is shown various animations of star trails and is asked to determine, based on these trails, in what hemisphere the student is standing and in which direction he is facing.

Question.Name: Star Trails Images
Question.Description: Star trails are shown in the sky and the students is asked to identify the appropriate latitude.

Question.Name: Star Paths: Declination Given
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation illustrating the diurnal path of a star of a certain declination and is asked to determine the observer's latitude.

Question.Name: Star Paths: Latitude Given
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a star's diurnal path as the Earth rotates, is given the latitude of the observer's location, and is asked to determine the star's declination.

Question.Name: Flat Map Dates
Question.Description: The student is shown a flat map of Earth, with dark regions and light regions representing day and night respectively, and is asked to determine the day of the year based on the pattern of these regions (solstices, equinoxes, or times in between).

Question.Name: Sun Rise/Set After Equinox
Question.Description: The student is told that the where the sun rises or sets on the either the Vernal or Autumnal Equinox, and is asked to determine where the sun will rise or set several weeks later.

Question.Name: Sun Shadow
Question.Description: Student is shown the shadow created by a gnomon at various times and asked to identify the direction north.

Question.Name: Seasons at the Union
Question.Description: The student is shown four pictures of the UNL Union plaza at various times of the year. Based on the length of the shadows, the student is asked to determine what time of year the picture was taken (the Autumnal or Vernal Equinoxes, or the Summer or Winter Solstices).

Question.Name: Sun at the Zenith
Question.Description: The student is told that he lives in the United States and that the sun passes through the zenith at some point during the year. He is then to determine, from a list of places, in which state he must live (from as far north as Alaska to as far south as Hawaii).

Question.Name: Change to Earth Seasons
Question.Description: The student is given both the eccentricity of Earth's orbit and its obliquity (tilt), and is asked to determine how the seasons would change with various changes in those two values.

Question.Name: Sun Paths 1
Question.Description: The student is shown various paths the sun makes through the sky on various days of the year (around the Autumnal or Vernal Equinoxes, or the Summer and Winter Solstices, among others) and is asked to determine at what latitude the observer is standing (the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, the north and south pole, the equator, and others).

Question.Name: Sun Paths 2
Question.Description: The student is shown various paths the sun makes through the sky at various latitudes around the Earth (the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, the north and south pole, the equator, and others) and is asked to determine what time of year it is (around the Autumnal or Vernal Equinoxes, or the Summer and Winter Solstices, among others).

Question.Name: Flat Map Hours
Question.Description: The student is shown a flat map of the Earth with the lighted areas representing daylight hours and the darker areas representing night hours, and is asked to determine for various latitudes the number of hours of daylight or night at certain times of the year (around the Autumnal or Vernal Equinoxes, or the Summer and Winter Solstices, among others).

Question.Name: North Point and Zenith
Question.Description: The student is told that a star's diurnal path takes it through both the zenith and the north point, and is asked to determine both the latitude of the observer and the declination of the star.

Question.Name: Average Daylight
Question.Description: The student is told of a person who lives at a certain latitude requested to do a school project that involves keeping track of daylight hours for every day out of the year. The student is then asked to determine what the average number of daylight hours during the whole year would be for these various locations.

Question.Name: Location Identification
Question.Description: The student is told that a certain location in the sky has a certain azimuth value and altitude value at an unknown latitude (azimuth of 180 degrees in the north, 0 degrees in the south, and altitude of 90 minus the latitude in both hemispheres) and is asked to determine what this location is (the intersection of the celestial equator and the observer's meridian).

Question.Name: Antipodes
Question.Description: Given the definition of antipodes, the student is asked to determine the antipodal spots for various locations across the globe (South America, United States, Spain, Hawaii, Greenland).

Question.Name: Rise and Set of Stars
Question.Description: The student is told that stars rise and set four minutes earlier each day (due to the Earth's revolution about the sun) and is asked how this would change if the Earth's rotation period increased.

Question.Name: Seasons on Uranus
Question.Description: The student is given Uranus' obliquity and orbital period and is asked to discuss what seasons would be like for various latitudes on the planet.

Question.Name: Missing Day
Question.Description: The student is told of Ferdinand Magellan's success at circumnavigating the world, and that he lost a day when he arrived at the Cape Verde Islands near Africa. The student is then asked to explain this (based on the concept of the International Dateline).

Question.Name: Antipodal Algorithm
Question.Description: Given New Zealand and Spain/Portugal as an example, the student is asked to develop an algorithm for determine antipodes.

Question.Name: Passive Solar Heating
Question.Description: Student is asked to explain the underlying sunlight motivations behind common choices of window direction and overhangs used in house construction.

Question.Name: Sun Glare
Question.Description: This discussion question ask students to identify the times of year, times of day, and directions where driving can be difficult.

Question.Name: Sun and Full Moon
Question.Description: The student is shown a picture of the full moon nearby the sun in the sky and is asked to describe why this could never happen.

Question.Name: Limb of the Moon
Question.Description: The student is shown a picture of a crescent moon with stars glimmering around and in front of it (the picture supposedly appeared in a magazine) and is asked to determine what is wrong with the picture.

Question.Name: Identify Phase from Picture
Question.Description: The student is shown various pictures of the moon in various phases and is asked simply to determine what phase the moon is in.

Question.Name: Phases of a Tree Trunk
Question.Description: The student is shown various snapshots of tree trunks lit on different sides (showing different 'phases' of the tree trunk), as well as a diagram of the observer of these trees. The photographer is placed at various angles with respect to the sun and the tree in the diagram (each position is labeled), and the student is asked to determine, based on the photo of the tree, at which position was photographer standing when the picture was taken.

Question.Name: Identify Lunar Position from Phase
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of the moon as it passes through its various phases and is asked to determine which numbered position corresponds to a certain phase based on the location of the moon with respect to the sun.

Question.Name: Phases of the Ecliptic
Question.Description: The student is asked what phase the moon would be in on different dates (the equinoxes and solstices) if it was on the ecliptic at the positions of one of the solstices or one of the equinoxes.

Question.Name: Phases, Eclipses and Tides
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of the moon at its various phases throughout its cycle and is asked to determine which phase of the moon is associated with a solar eclipse, a lunar eclipse, neap tides, and spring tides.

Question.Name: Phase Evolution
Question.Description: The student is told that the moon is full at a certain time and is asked either what phase the moon will be in a given amount of time later (phase evolution), or is given the full moon's rising time and is asked to determine its rising time the day after.

Question.Name: Time Intervals Between Phases
Question.Description: The student is shown a picture of the moon in a certain phase and then is shown an animation of the change in phase over a certain period of time. The student is asked to determine what that time interval is based on the animation.

Question.Name: Rising/Meridian/Setting Times
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of the moon in its various phases and is asked to determine for different phases at what time the moon would rise, set, or appear at the meridian.

Question.Name: Lunar Periods
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of the moon orbiting the Earth as the Earth revolves about the sun and is asked to determine whether the animation shown represents the moon's synodic period, sidereal period, or neither.

Question.Name: Types of Lunar Eclipses
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of the moon as it is positioned relative to the Earth's shadow and is asked to determine what kind of eclipse a nighttime viewer would see (total lunar, penumbral, partial lunar, or none).

Question.Name: Frequency of Eclipses
Question.Description: The student is given a list of dates when either solar or lunar eclipses were observed and is asked to determine which date on the list could not be possible based on the frequency of eclipses.

Question.Name: Synchronous Rotation
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a father spinning his son Joey around out of excitement that the new jersey he bought his son matches his own, while the mother looks on from a distance. The student is then asked to determine which of a following series of statements is false, based on the synchronous rotation of the father and his son.

Question.Name: Horizon Diagram: Identify Phase
Question.Description: The student is shown a horizon diagram with the moon located at a certain position and is given a certain time that the moon is appearing at this position. He is then asked to determine what phase the moon is in based on this position and time.

Question.Name: Horizon Diagram: Identify Time
Question.Description: The student is shown a horizon diagram with the moon located at a certain position and is given the moon's phase. He is then asked to determine what time this represents.

Question.Name: Location of the Moon
Question.Description: The student is told how astronomers use occultation information to improve their knowledge of orbits of objects and is asked to determine when an astronomer would be able to determine more about the lunar orbit if and when it occults Polaris.

Question.Name: Altitude of the Moon
Question.Description: The student is told the sad story of Reginald, the UNL professor of astronomy turned werewolf, who continues only to observe the maximum altitude of the moon at various times of the year. The student is asked during what month would the maximum altitude of the moon be greatest.

Question.Name: Earthrise on the Moon
Question.Description: The student is shown the famous picture of the Earthrise as taken during the Apollo 11 mission and is asked to determine based on the phase of the Earth what phase the moon would be in as seen from the Earth at the time the photo was taken.

Question.Name: Location of the Crescent Moon
Question.Description: The student is told of the significance of the first waxing crescent moon in the Muslim religion and is asked to determine where one would look for it in the sky and at what time.

Question.Name: Earth's Speed Changes
Question.Description: The student is asked how the moon's synodic period would change if the Earth's orbital period changed (increased, descreased, or was negated).

Question.Name: Earth Phases
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of the Earth as it orbits the sun and is asked to determine at what positions on the diagram the Earth would be at various phases as seen from Mars.

Question.Name: Phases Visible
Question.Description: The student is given a particular time and asked what phases of the moon can be seen throughout the month at this time.

Question.Name: Length of Night
Question.Description: The student is shown a triangle rotating on the surface of the moon and and asked how long the triangle will be in the lunar night.

Question.Name: Moon's Plane is Perpendicular
Question.Description: The student is asked how the phases of the moon and the cycle of eclipses throughout the year would change if the moon had an orbit perpendicular to the plane of the sun.

Question.Name: Phases from the North Pole
Question.Description: The student is told that the moon is on the horizon in the middle of Autumn as seen from the North Pole and is asked how many days of toy-making are left.

Question.Name: Tides in the Future
Question.Description: The student is told that because of tidal interactions between the moon and the Earth, the Earth's rotational period is slowing and the moon's orbit is growing larger. The student is then asked to determine how frequency and strength of tides will have changed in the future because of this interaction.

Question.Name: Realistic Animation?
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a planet orbiting a star and is asked to determine how realistic the animation is using Kepler's laws.

Question.Name: Eccentricity of Shapes
Question.Description: The student is shown variously shaped objects (Easter egg, watermelon, basketball, and a Cuban cigar) and is asked to determine which has the largest/smallest eccentricity.

Question.Name: Kepler's 2nd Law
Question.Description: The student is shown a schematic of an orbit and is asked to determine at which point the object is moving with the greatest/least speed; also, the student is shown various areas swept out by an object in orbit and, from a timescale of sweeping, is asked to determine which area is larger/smaller.

Question.Name: Table: Kepler's 3rd Law
Question.Description: The student is shown a table of various solar system objects and their respective periods and semi-major axes and is asked to determine what the period/semi-major axis would be for a given object given its semi-major axis/period.

Question.Name: Synodic/Sidereal Periods 1
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of Earth and Mars/Venus orbiting the sun and is asked to determine if the animation illustrates the sidereal/synodic period of Earth or Mars/Venus.

Question.Name: Mars Elongation
Question.Description: The student is shown several schematics of Mars and Earth in two places in their orbits with accompanying angles between them and the sun drawn and is asked to determine which illustrates the elongation of Mars.

Question.Name: Elongation Values
Question.Description: The student is shown a schematic of the Earth and another object in either a superior or inferior orbit and is asked to determine values of the elongation for different places in the object's orbit.

Question.Name: Elongation Terminology
Question.Description: The student is shown a schematic of the Earth and another object in either a superior or inferior orbit and is asked to name various positions in the object's orbit (opposition, quadrature or conjunction for superior orbits, inferior/superior conjunction or greatest elongation for inferior orbits).

Question.Name: Phases of Venus - Copernican
Question.Description: The student is shown a schematic of Earth and Venus in their respective heliocentric (Copernican) orbits and is asked to determine in what phase would be for various positions relative to Earth.

Question.Name: Phases of Venus - Ptolemaic
Question.Description: The student is shown a schematic of Earth and Venus in their respective Ptolemaic orbits and is asked to determine in what phase would be for various positions relative to Earth.

Question.Name: Perihelion/Aphelion Distance
Question.Description: The student is shown an object's orbit of 10 AU and is asked to determine based on its given eccentricity what its perihelion/aphelion distance would be.

Question.Name: Applying Newton's Laws 1
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a boy spinning a rock on a string above his head and is asked to determine what path the rock will likely take after he lets go (inertia).

Question.Name: Gravity Fundamentals
Question.Description: General questions about the form and direction of the Law of Gravity.

Question.Name: Gravity Direction
Question.Description: Student is asked to identify correct directions and strengths of gravitational forces.

Question.Name: Animations of Orbits
Question.Description: The student is shown numerous animations of hypothetical orbits and is asked to determine which is realistic; also, the student is shown an object in circular orbit and is asked to determine how many forces are acting on it.

Question.Name: Gravity Formula
Question.Description: Students are asked about the resulting effect on the force between two point masses if a change to either mass or the separation is made, i.e. what happens to the force is mass one is doubled?

Question.Name: Gravity Calculations 1
Question.Description: Calculations involving gravity between point masses of increasing complexity.

Question.Name: Gravity Calculations 2
Question.Description: More calculations involving gravity between point masses of increasing complexity.

Question.Name: Gravity Calculations 3
Question.Description: Still more calculations involving gravity between point masses of increasing complexity.

Question.Name: Gravity Calculations 4
Question.Description: Given the sun's gravitational force exerted on the Earth, the student is asked to determine the Earth's gravitational force on the sun (larger, smaller, or the same).

Question.Name: Earth Force vs. Sun Force
Question.Description: The student is shown a schematic of a hypothetical solar system, with planet masses given in terms of Jupiter masses and is asked to determine based on distance and mass what planet would exert the greatest/least gravitational force on the parent star.

Question.Name: Spaceship to the Moon
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a rocket moving between the Earth and the moon and is asked to determine at which labeled points the gravitational force is greatest from the Earth or the moon or is nearly equal from both.

Question.Name: Satellite Orbits
Question.Description: Student is asked about the orbital period of a geosynchronous satellite.

Question.Name: Forces and Motion
Question.Description: Student is asked to reason regarding the number of forces that can be acting on an objects from its motion.

Question.Name: Graph: Orbital Velocities
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine which of four graphs best illustrates orbital velocity versus distance for objects in circular orbit.

Question.Name: Graph: Kepler's 3rd Law
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine which of four graphs with axes period versus average distance correctly shows Kepler's third law.

Question.Name: Graph: Synodic Periods
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine which of four graphs show the correct relationship between synodic period and radius of a circular orbit.

Question.Name: Synodic/Sidereal Periods 2
Question.Description: Given the orbits of various objects (a hypothetical asteroid, the satellite Snoopy, and Varuna), the student is asked to determine the length of its synodic or sidereal period (long, short, about a year).

Question.Name: Orbital Parameters (Sedna)
Question.Description: Given the perihelion and aphelion distances of Sedna, the student is asked to determine what its eccentricity and semi-major axis are.

Question.Name: Spider on a Clock
Question.Description: The student is told that a spider jumps onto the minute hand of a clock and there remains and is asked to determine how often the spider will have another chance to jump to the hour hand (synodic period of the hands).

Question.Name: Goat in a Field
Question.Description: The student is told of a farmer who has a goat in a rectangular field, attached by two chains to two separate stakes at two corners of the field, and is asked to determine what kind of path the goat can make while grazing (circle, parabola, ellipse, rectangle, square).

Question.Name: Kepler's 2nd and 3rd Laws
Question.Description: The student is shown the orbit of an asteroid (circular or elliptical), is given the semi-major axis length, and is asked to determine how long it would take to get from a point A on the orbit to a point B for various positions of A and B.

Question.Name: Constructing An Ellipse
Question.Description: The student is told that someone wants to draw an ellipse with a given semi-major axis and eccentricity using a pencil, a string, and two thumbtacks, and is asked to determine what length the string should be for the various values of e and a.

Question.Name: Planetary Motion
Question.Description: The student is told that Mars rises at the same time as a given star and is asked to determine if it will rise earlier/later than the star for a regular prograde motion or a retrograde motion.

Question.Name: Orbital Velocity Formula
Question.Description: Student is asked to compare the orbital velocities of Mercury and Pluto using the formula and their distances from the sun.

Question.Name: Semi-Minor Axis
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the equation for the semi-minor axis of ellipse in terms of the semi-major axis and the eccentricity.

Question.Name: Venusian Elongation
Question.Description: The student is asked to identify the elongation of Earth as seen from Venus when Venus is at greatest elongation.

Question.Name: Orbit of Asteroid 1991VG
Question.Description: The student is told that asteroid 1991VG has an orbit close to Earth's and an eccentricity of .05, is given a table of dates of close approaches, and is asked to explain a pattern in the dates using elongation concepts.

Question.Name: Direction of Rainfall
Question.Description: Told that an astronomer must tilt his umbrella forward while running and upward while standing still to protect himself from falling rain, the student is asked about a connection between this observation and the Ptolemaic/Copernican debate over whether or not the Earth moves.

Question.Name: Applying Newton's Laws 2
Question.Description: Shown a picture of an astronaut drifting from her spaceship (and holding a wrench), the student is asked how the astronaut could apply Newton's laws of motion to help her get back.

Question.Name: Potassium Flares
Question.Description: The student is told of a discovery in France of potassium lines in a stellar spectrum, and is asked to determine why this would be unusual and to propose an alternate explanation based on the accompanying image.

Question.Name: Space Lasers
Question.Description: The student is reminded of how sci-fi movies typically include ships that can shoot lasers, and is asked to determine how an observer can actually see them in space.

Question.Name: Properties of Waves
Question.Description: The student is shown four pictures of waves and is asked to determine which has the longest or shortest wavelength, and the largest or smallest amplitude.

Question.Name: Sizes of Wavelengths
Question.Description: The student is asked to compare various wavelengths of light to sizes of different objects (atom, bacteria, fingertip, mountain).

Question.Name: EM Spectrum Parameters
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine for various bands in the electromagnetic spectrum which has the largest/smallest wavelength, energy, frequency, and velocity in space.

Question.Name: Number Line: EM Spectrum
Question.Description: The student is shown the electromagnetic spectrum and an arrow pointing either to the right or left, and is asked to determine which parameters follow the arrow (wavelength, energy, and frequency).

Question.Name: Photon Speeds
Question.Description: The student is shown a blackbody spectrum for the sun and is asked to determine a difference in when photons of different energies will arrive at the Earth (speed of light question).

Question.Name: Electron Transitions
Question.Description: The student is shown an energy level transition diagram for an electron, and is asked to determine how the binding energy changes and whether a photon is absorbed or emitted.

Question.Name: Permitted Electron Orbits #1
Question.Description: The student is shown various electron orbitals for a fictitious atom and their respective energies, and is asked to determine from a list which photon energy can be absorbed or emitted for the electron to make a valid transition.

Question.Name: Permitted Electron Orbits #2
Question.Description: The student is shown various electron orbitals for a different fictitious atom and their respective energies, and is asked to determine from a list which photon energy can be absorbed or emitted for the electron to make a valid transition.

Question.Name: H Energy Level Transitions
Question.Description: The student is shown a hydrogen energy level transition diagram and is asked to determine which labeled transition corresponds to a)Balmer lines alpha, beta, and gamma, and b)Lyman alpha being absorbed or emitted.

Question.Name: Ranking Electron Transitions
Question.Description: The student is shown various transitions on a hydrogen energy level diagram and is asked to determine which has the greatest energy, wavelength, or frequency.

Question.Name: Misc Doppler Shift
Question.Description: This questions contains several different parts, including: a)determining which way a star is moving by shifted wavelength of absorption lines, b)determining which way a police car is moving by measuring a shift in frequency of its siren, c)determining which way quasars move by acknowledging that they all seem to have high redshift, and d)determining based on direction of motion which speeding car would get a ticket from an officer using a radar gun.

Question.Name: Hydrogen Doppler Shift
Question.Description: Given various hydrogen spectra to compare to the original, unshifted spectrum, the student is asked to determine which is most redshifted/blueshifted or is moving away/approaching the observer the fastest.

Question.Name: Racetrack Radar
Question.Description: The student is shown a car moving on a racetrack and a man with a radar gun measuring his speed, and is asked to determine at which point on the track the gun would detect the highest/lowest speed/velocity.

Question.Name: Spaceship Doppler Shifts
Question.Description: The student is shown an image of two alien spaceships in a battle, firing lasers at each other, and is asked to determine based on direction of motion if the laser fire from one spaceship would be redshifted/blueshifted/unchanged from the point of view of the ship being fired upon.

Question.Name: Blackbody Curve Units
Question.Description: The student is shown images of blackbody curves for various stars of various temperatures and sizes, and is asked to determine the units on the y-axis for each set (luminosity units or flux).

Question.Name: Blackbody Curve Laws
Question.Description: The student is shown various blackbody curves with given temperatures, and is asked to determine how the area under the curve would change for changing temperature.

Question.Name: Blackbody Curve Colors
Question.Description: The student is shown various blackbody curves for various temperatures and is asked to determine what color the respective star would be.

Question.Name: Blackbody Curve Temperatures
Question.Description: The student is shown four blackbody curves on one graph and is asked to determine (based on the units given for y, luminosity or flux) which would indicate the highest/lowest temperature, or the highest/lowest radius for the respective star.

Question.Name: Distant Star Light
Question.Description: The student is shown starlight of intensity I hitting a square and is asked to determine what the intensity of the light is on a subset of that square or on a subset of a square behind the incident square.

Question.Name: Flux Fraction 1
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of the sun at the center or either a sphere or a cube, and is asked to determine the flux through the shaded area on the surface.

Question.Name: Flux Fraction 2
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of the sun at the center of an orbit or 10 AU and is asked to determine what the value of the flux would be at that location (in terms of solar luminosities).

Question.Name: Inverse Square Flux
Question.Description: Taking into account a diagram of concentric spheres at various distances from the sun as a light source, the student is asked to determine, based on a grid pattern drawn out by the sun's rays, what the value of the flux is in one square of the grid given the value of another in a different sphere.

Question.Name: Spectrum Analogies
Question.Description: The student is asked to compare various spectra to emission/absorption/continuous spectra of light (screw sizes in a hardware store, radio station choices, number line missing the Fibonacci sequence, violin notes played in a glissando, piano keys played in sequence, or a slide whistler with the hiccups).

Question.Name: Spectra Perspective 1
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of a light bulb shining on a cloud of gas and is asked to determine what kind of spectrum (continuous, emission, absorption) an observer from various angles would see.

Question.Name: Spectra Perspective 2
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of a light bulb shining on a cloud of gas and is asked to determine from what angle an observer would likely see the spectrum of a star or of its chromosphere during an eclipse.

Question.Name: Spectroscopic Arithmetic
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine an arithmetic equation for spectra, using C = continuous, A = absorption, and E = emission.

Question.Name: Types of Spectra Venn Diagram
Question.Description: Given a Venn diagram of spectra (continuous, emission, and absorption overlapping), the student is asked to determine where in the diagram various kinds of spectra would be located (some/all wavelengths present, produced by chromosphere/Stefan-Boltzmann law/Kirchoff's laws/a hot, dense gas/typical stars).

Question.Name: Properties Table
Question.Description: A table is used to probe student understanding of the relationships between wavelength, frequency, and energy.

Question.Name: Observing in Different EM Bands
Question.Description: Students are asked about wavelength bands of the EM spectrum and what they might be good for observing.

Question.Name: Deductions from H-alpha Wavelength
Question.Description: This question focuses on what can be determined from the wavelength of a spectral line and what can't be determined.

Question.Name: Absorption Lines and Color
Question.Description: Question probes some misconceptions that students have regarding color and spectral lines.

Question.Name: Graph: EM Spectrum
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose between various graphs of energy vs. wavelength vs. frequency (electromagnetic spectrum parameters) to determine correct relationships between them.

Question.Name: Graph: Siren Frequency
Question.Description: The student is shown an observer watching a car-chase, a police car with sirens blaring chasing after another car, and is asked to choose the graph that best represents the frequency change as the cars go by from the observer's point of view and from that of the car being chased.

Question.Name: Table: Blackbody Descriptions
Question.Description: Given a table of temperatures, fluxes, and peak wavelengths, the student is asked to determine which star (with the values in the table) has the largest/smallest flux/temperature/peak wavelength (blackbody, Wien's law).

Question.Name: Moving Hydrogen Clouds
Question.Description: The student is shown a schematic of various moving clouds of hydrogen relative to a light bulb and is asked to determine, based on the velocities of the clouds and the position of the observer, which spectrum would the observer likely see.

Question.Name: Atmospheric Windows
Question.Description: Given that the Zendari starship is beaming a full spectrum of light down to Earth, the student is asked to choose the graph that best represents the spectrum an earthbound observer would detect (atmospheric windows for light).

Question.Name: Experimental Chamber
Question.Description: The student is told of an argument between Dr. Jones and Dr. Singh about the nature of the spectrum of the gas in their experimental chamber for heating gases and is asked to determine who would see what kind of spectrum (emission, absorption, continuous).

Question.Name: Sirius Images
Question.Description: Students are asked to compare images of Sirius and its white dwarf companion in different EM bands.

Question.Name: Heating a Horseshoe
Question.Description: Shown a blacksmith heating a horseshoe to malleability, the student is asked what kind of spectrum the shoe gives off at various points during heating.

Question.Name: Pulsating Star
Question.Description: The student is asked to describe what the spectrum of a pulsating star would look like over time in terms of Doppler shift and changing temperature and size.

Question.Name: Wave Parameters
Question.Description: The student is asked how he would go about measuring wavelength, frequency, and velocity of incoming ocean waves with only simple tools.

Question.Name: Discharge Tube Spectrum
Question.Description: The student is shown the appearrance of a hydrogen discharge tube as seen through a diffraction grating and asked to sketch the spectrum.

Question.Name: Refraction
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of a ray of light going between two media of different indexes of refraction and is asked to determine the direction of the outgoing ray after passing through the border between materials.

Question.Name: Reflection
Question.Description: The student is shown an incident ray of light on a mirror (either a flat mirror or a laser on a two-dimensional corner reflector) and is asked to determine the direction of the outgoing ray of light.

Question.Name: Lenses
Question.Description: The student is shown various diagrams for light reaching a converging/diverging lens and is asked to determine which illustrates best the light's path for a source at the focal point of the converging lens or for the diverging lens.

Question.Name: Simple Refracting Telescope
Question.Description: The student is asked simply if a simple refracting telescope has a long or short objective lens focal length and a long or short eyepiece focal length.

Question.Name: Beam and Lenses
Question.Description: The student is shown two lenses, separated by a distance of their two focal lengths added together, and is asked to what path outgoing light would make after passing through the second lens.

Question.Name: Light Gathering Power
Question.Description: The student is told he's stuck on a deserted island and can only gather water from rainfall using materials at hand, and he is asked what would have the best water collecting capacity: seashell, mudbowl, coconut, or straw basket; also, the student is asked to determine the ratio of light gathering power between various aperture telescopes.

Question.Name: Magnification and Field of View
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine for various changes in lens size how the magnification/field of view would change (increase, decrease, stay the same).

Question.Name: Hubble Space Telescope
Question.Description: The student is asked what was so impressive about the Hubble Space Telescope: light gathering/resolving/magnifying power.

Question.Name: Spherical Aberration
Question.Description: The student is shown four ray diagrams indicating reflection off of a spherical mirror and is asked to determine which most correctly illustrates where they gather (spherical aberration).

Question.Name: James Webb Telescope
Question.Description: The student is asked to compare for the James Webb telescope (with its many hexagonal segments) light gathering power and resolving power for one segment as opposed to all 18.

Question.Name: CCD Response Function
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine which graph represents the correct description of the response function of a pixel on a CCD; also, the student is asked what other pixel response function would look like compared to a basis function.

Question.Name: Spearfishing
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine where a boy hunting fish with a spear should aim to hit his target (due to light refraction in water).

Question.Name: Telescope Shopping
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine a cost to light gathering power ratio for various telescopes of given aperture while telescope shopping at Mort's Telescope Store.

Question.Name: Mirror, Mirror
Question.Description: The student is told that a man Roger bought a new 3 foot mirror to mount on his wall, and since Roger is six feet tall, the student is asked where Roger should place the mirror to see as much of himself as possible.

Question.Name: HST View
Question.Description: Students are asked to picture themselves leading a science outreach event and responding to a child who believes that the HST gets a better view because it is closer to the stars.

Question.Name: Thermal Transport
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the primary method of thermal transport in: a heating lamp for pizza, the handle of a spoon in a pot on an oven burner, and a lava lamp.

Question.Name: H, He Abundance Over Time
Question.Description: The student is shown four graph and is asked to determine which most accurately illustrates the evolution in hydrogen and helium composition for a star over time.

Question.Name: Outcome of Fusion
Question.Description: The student is asked what the correct basic fusion reactions and outputs are for proton-proton chains, the CNO cycle, and the triple alpha process.

Question.Name: Cause of Sunspots
Question.Description: Students are asked to explain why sunspots appear dark.

Question.Name: Rotation of Sunspots
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the period of rotation of a star based on an animation showing the rotation of a sunspot on the star.

Question.Name: Sun's Blackbody Curves
Question.Description: The student is asked to differentiate between the blackbody curve of the sun itself and of a sunspot on the sun.

Question.Name: Sunspot Rotation
Question.Description: Given an initial picture of three sunspots viewed by an observer in the northern-hemisphere, the student is asked to determine what the placement of the sunspots would look like two days later (due to differential rotation).

Question.Name: Sun Changes Over Time
Question.Description: Soho images of the sun showing the number of sunspots are used to explore the sun's magnetic cycle.

Question.Name: Nature of Photosphere
Question.Description: The student is asked why light isn't visible for material above/below the photosphere (due to density and opacity).

Question.Name: Energy Transport Mechanisms
Question.Description: The student is asked what causes granulation on the sun's surface; also, the student is asked which (convection, conduction, radiation) mechanism is most prominent in the center/surface of the star.

Question.Name: Nuclear Reaction Photon
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose the image that best represents the path of a photon produced in the center of the sun by nuclear fusion as it makes its way out of the star; also, the student is asked when and how the photon will the center of a star (long/short time later as a single/many photons).

Question.Name: Granulation
Question.Description: The student is asked why dark/light spots on the surface of the sun appear dark/light (making granulation; due to convection mechanisms: hot material rising or falling, cool material rising or falling).

Question.Name: Spectra
Question.Description: The student is asked what kind of spectrum the sun's photosphere/corona produces and what we see (continuous, absorption, emission).

Question.Name: Pressure vs. Depth
Question.Description: The student is shown a diagram of a diver, mermaid, submarine, bathysphere, and a sea monster at various points relative to the ocean floor, and is asked to compare the hydrostatic pressure exerted on these characters relative to each other.

Question.Name: Tire Check
Question.Description: Students are asked about the air pressure in a tire as temperature changes.

Question.Name: Binding Energy
Question.Description: The student is asked to compare energies released from/required to fuse/split iron, gold, and aluminum, and is asked to compare the energies released by fission of uranium and fusion of hydrogen.

Question.Name: Corona Ionization
Question.Description: The student is told of the multiply ionized heavy elements in the corona of the sun and is asked to determine the cause (charge, radioactivity, density, temperature, or susceptibility to magnetic fields).

Question.Name: Solar Wind Particles
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine what the makeup of the solar wind is (protons, electrons, ionized atoms, neutral atoms).

Question.Name: Solar Properties Plots
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine which graph best represents how the sun's luminosity/temperature/density varies with distance from the sun's center.

Question.Name: Deflection of Charged Particles #1
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the paths of particles (protons, electrons, and neutrons) from a particle gun as they move through a magnetic field for a field pointing inward/outward and increasing/descreasing.

Question.Name: Deflection of Charged Particles #2
Question.Description: The student is given the paths of particles shot from a particle gun (electrons, protons, and neutrons) and is asked to determine the paths of a second kind of particle shot from a nearby particle gun through the same field.

Question.Name: Molecular Clouds
Question.Description: The student is asked what affects the likelihood of stars forming in a molecular cloud (mass, temperature, radius).

Question.Name: Gravity vs. Thermal Pressure
Question.Description: The student is asked if a larger/smaller mass makes it more likely for star formation to occur in a molecular cloud (gravity overcomes pressure) or if mass doesn't play a role.

Question.Name: Preferential Scattering (Pleiades)
Question.Description: The student is asked to compare the scattering (not preferential) processes taking place in a cloud versus that in the Pleiades constellation.

Question.Name: Star Formation in a Molecular Cloud
Question.Description: Shown a graph of density through the cross-section of a molecular cloud, the student is asked to determine where the most likely place for star formation is.

Question.Name: Preferential Scattering (Lines)
Question.Description: Shown a picture of lines of light passing through a blue molecular cloud, the student is asked to determine based on frequency of scattering which line represents red or blue.

Question.Name: Wavelengths
Question.Description: The student is shown a graph of the spectrum of white light (a straight line on a spectrum plot), is told that a beam of light passes through a cloud and into a detector, and is asked to determine which plot represents the light seen in the detector after scattering has occurred.

Question.Name: Star Formation Masses
Question.Description: Possible bar graphs are shown describing the relative abundance that low-mass, sun-like, and high-mass stars form.

Question.Name: Wise Adage
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose which 'wise adage' from a list of four is generally true (blue/red stars are found near blue/red clouds).

Question.Name: Emission Nebula Energy Source
Question.Description: From a plot of various blackbodies, the student is asked to determine (knowing that short wavelength photons ionize hydrogen more readily) which would be most likely to produce an emission nebula.

Question.Name: EGGs Analogy
Question.Description: Rock formations in Utah are used as an analaogy for evaporating gaseous globules.

Question.Name: Apparent Magnitudes from Image
Question.Description: The student is shown a field of stars of various apparent brightness and is asked to determine which is apparent magnitude 1 or 5.

Question.Name: Apparent Magnitude and Brightness
Question.Description: The student is given the apparent magnitudes of various known stars (Deneb, Mimosa, Altair, Polaris, Merak, and Sirius) and is asked to compare their brightness.

Question.Name: Brightness and Energy of Stars
Question.Description: The student is given the apparent and absolute magnitudes of various stars (Avior, Alkaid, Wolf 359, Barnard's Star, Acrux, Aldebaran, Deneb, Arcturus) and is asked to compare their apparent brightness and the amount of energy they emit.

Question.Name: Estimating Absolute Magnitude
Question.Description: The student is given the apparent magnitudes and distances of various stars (Arcturus, HIP 76362, Rigel) and is asked to estimate their absolute magnitudes.

Question.Name: Estimating Apparent Magnitude
Question.Description: The student is given the absolute magnitudes of various stars (Ross 154, Sol, HD 6658) and is asked to estimate its apparent magnitude.

Question.Name: Magnitude and Distance
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine how absolute and apparent magnitudes change with increasing or decreasing distance of a star.

Question.Name: Distance Modulus
Question.Description: The student is given both the apparent and the absolute magnitudes of various stars (Fomalhaut, Wolf 359, Deneb) and is asked to estimate their distance using the distance modulus formula.

Question.Name: Speed Trap
Question.Description: Shown a picture of two cars both going 50 mph and a police car measuring their speeds with a radar gun, the student is asked to determine which would get the ticket.

Question.Name: Motion Units
Question.Description: The student is asked to differentiate between proper motion units and tangential/radial velocity units for moving stars.

Question.Name: Proper Motion from Image
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine, based on two images of a star field taken 20 years apart, which star shows the most/least proper motion/tangential velocity/radial velocity.

Question.Name: Table: Stellar Velocities
Question.Description: The student is given a table with various stars' radial velocities, distances, and proper motions, and is asked to determine which would have the largest/smallest tangential/space velocities.

Question.Name: Tangential Velocity
Question.Description: Given a diagram of various stars of various distances and tangential velocities (as vectors), the student is asked to determine which would have the largest/smallest proper motion.

Question.Name: Ranking Stellar Motions
Question.Description: Given various stellar motions as arrows of different lengths, the student is asked to determine which has the largest/smallest proper motion/tangential velocity/radial velocity.

Question.Name: Proper Motion of Barnard's Star
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the cause of Barnard's Star's high proper motion (distance, tangential, radial, or space velocity).

Question.Name: Types of Motion
Question.Description: Given two trails of two different stars sketched out over a period of 2000 years, the student is asked to compare their space velocities and proper motions.

Question.Name: Thirty Closest Stars
Question.Description: The student is asked what value for the thirty closest stars is highest: radial/tangential velocities, surface temperature, radii, or proper motion.

Question.Name: Collision Course
Question.Description: The student is asked if a star on a collision course with our solar system would have positive/negative/zero radial/tangential velocity.

Question.Name: Eta Carinae Magnitude Change
Question.Description: The student is told of the drastic change in magnitude of the star Eta Carinae and is asked to determine what the change in intensity received from the star on Earth would be.

Question.Name: Components of Space Velocity
Question.Description: The student is given the space velocity of a star and either the tangential or the radial velocity, and is asked to determine the other.

Question.Name: Algol in the Past
Question.Description: The student is told the star Algol's distance and apparent magnitude 7.2 million years in the past, its distance today, and is asked to determine its apparent magnitude today.

Question.Name: Magnitude of Sirius B
Question.Description: Given the apparent magnitude of Sirius A and told that it is approximately 10000 times brighter than its companion white dwarf Sirius B, the student is asked to determine the apparent magnitude of Sirius B.

Question.Name: Temperature and Color
Question.Description: The student is shown a picture of a heat dial for a car heating system and is asked what an astronomer would think of the color coding used to denote the temperature setting.

Question.Name: L-R-T Relation With HR Diagram
Question.Description: Given two stars and their placement on an HR diagram, the student is asked to determine which would be bigger/smaller (radius) if the stars are in the same column/row and one is hotter/colder (temperature) or more/less luminous than the other.

Question.Name: L-R-T Relation
Question.Description: Given that two stars have equal/bigger/smaller temperatures/luminosities, the student is asked to determine which has the larger radius.

Question.Name: Stellar Luminosity Comparisons
Question.Description: Shown two stars to compare (red or blue, big or small), the student is asked to compare their luminosities.

Question.Name: Luminosity Table
Question.Description: Given a table of radii and luminosities for stars of various temperatures with one value filled in, the student is asked to determine where else that value would be placed in the table.

Question.Name: Luminosity Formula
Question.Description: The student is given the radius/temperature/luminosity of a star as compared to the sun and is asked to determine what the temperature/luminosity/radius of a star of a different value of radius/temperature/luminosity (in solar units) would be.

Question.Name: HR Diagram #1
Question.Description: Shown various stars in various places on an HR diagram (either with luminosity and temperature axes or magnitude and spectral type), the student is asked to determine which star has the largest/smallest luminosity/temperature.

Question.Name: Stellar Parameters
Question.Description: Given various stars on the HR Diagram, the student is asked to determine which has the largest/smallest radius/mass.

Question.Name: Conceptual HR Diagram
Question.Description: Given four graphs of temperature against luminosity, with various directions for increasing parameters, and a line pointing in the direction of increasing radius/mass, the student is to pick which best represents a real HR Diagram.

Question.Name: HR Groups
Question.Description: The student is asked what kinds of stars are most common on the HR Diagram (in terms of luminosity and radius) and what kind are the brightest we can see (in the same parameters).

Question.Name: Perspectives
Question.Description: This question asks students to identify the perspective indicated by an arrow in a top-view of an old west theme.

Question.Name: Parallax and Distance
Question.Description: The student is shown the parallax/distance of various stars (Capella, Rigel, Sirius, Polaris) and is asked to determine its distance/parallax, or simply given a parallax/distance of an object, the student is asked to calculate the object's distance/parallax.

Question.Name: Errors in Spectroscopic Parallax
Question.Description: Given a star's spectral type, luminosity class, and apparent magnitude, the student is asked to determine what kind of change in the measured distance would occur if it was discovered that the star was really of a different spectral type, luminosity class, or apparent magnitude.

Question.Name: Spectral Type Temperature Ranking
Question.Description: Given the spectral type of a certain star (the sun, Sirius, Aldebaran, Polaris, Rigel), the student is asked to determine what type would be slightly cooler/hotter (temperature) than the given star.

Question.Name: Spectral Type Number Line
Question.Description: Shown a number line pointing to the left and labeled with spectral types and their corresponding colors, the student is asked to determine what parameter would be increasing with the line's direction (temperature, mass, velocity, luminosity).

Question.Name: Line Strength 1
Question.Description: Given a graph showing H absorption line strength dependence on spectral type, the student is asked to determine line strengths for various spectral types.

Question.Name: Line Strength 2
Question.Description: Given a graph showing H absorption line strength dependence on spectral type, the student is asked why stars on opposite lines of the temperature spectrum have weak lines (abundance of neutral, excited, or ionized atoms).

Question.Name: Common Stars
Question.Description: Given a function of abundance of stars for values of absolute magnitude, the student is asked to determine which stars would appear at the peak between 12 and 17 Mv (red giants, blue supergiants, red dwarfs, white/yellow main sequence stars).

Question.Name: Number of Visible Stars
Question.Description: Given a function of abundance of stars for values of absolute magnitude and that the lowest apparent magnitude visible is around 6, the student is asked to determine how many stars would be visible within 10 parsecs.

Question.Name: Sun's Relative Luminosity
Question.Description: Given a function of abundance of stars for values of absolute magnitude and that the sun has an Mv of around 4.78, the student is asked to determine whether the majority of stars in our stellar neighborhood are brighter or dimmer than the sun.

Question.Name: Parsec Size
Question.Description: Told that there was a debate between Martian and Venusian astronomers over the size of a parsec at the European Astrophysics Conference, the student is asked whose parsec is bigger and by how much.

Question.Name: Table: Parallax Data
Question.Description: Given a table of a data (including distance in parsecs, parallax, and absolute and apparent magnitudes) for various stars, the student is asked to determine which star is closest/farther, has the most/least luminosity, and is brightest/dimmest in the sky.

Question.Name: Property Ranges
Question.Description: The student is asked to rank luminosity, mass, radius, and temperature in terms of which parameter has the biggest to least range of acceptable values for stars.

Question.Name: Parallax from Jupiter
Question.Description: The student is told that Hipparcos IV, a satellite to be sent out in 2042 to measure parallax, is put in orbit around Jupiter, and is asked to discuss the advantages/disadvantages of this arrangement.

Question.Name: Practical Center of Mass
Question.Description: Students are asked to balance "teeter-totter-like" situations.

Question.Name: CM Definition
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify the location of the center of mass.

Question.Name: Binary Center of Mass
Question.Description: Several options ask students to identify the location of the CM for a binary system.

Question.Name: Mass-Luminosity Relation
Question.Description: Students are asked to calculate luminosity when given mass.

Question.Name: Optical Double Car
Question.Description: Different observing perspective at a demolition derby are used to explore visual binaries and optical double stars.

Question.Name: Binary Types
Question.Description: Shown an image of two stars apparently nearby each other and given their right ascensions, declinations, and distances, the student is asked to determine what kind of binary they form (visual/astrometric/spectroscopic/eclipsing binary, or an optical double).

Question.Name: Binary Systems 1
Question.Description: Several binary systems with stellar positions and directions of motions indicated are provided and the students is asked to predict the correct one.

Question.Name: Binary Kepler's 3rd Law
Question.Description: The student is given a table of the masses of members of binary system and asked to identify the system with the largest separation.

Question.Name: Binary Systems2
Question.Description: The student is the location of one member of a binary system and asked to identify the location and direction of the other.

Question.Name: Binary Star Properties
Question.Description: Students are shown an animation of two stars in a binary system and asked bout their periods, mass, and speeds.

Question.Name: Eclipsing Variables
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a binary system (that can be manipulated by the instructor) and asked to identify which variable (inclination, radii, and/or separation) affect whether or not eclipses are observed.

Question.Name: Light Curve Shape
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a binary system (that can be manipulated by the instructor) and asked to crudely describe the shape of the binary.

Question.Name: Eclipsing Binary Light Curves 1
Question.Description: Student is shown an eclipsing binary light curve and asked to identify how the tempertaures and sizes of the two stars compare.

Question.Name: Eclipsing Binary Light Curves 2
Question.Description: The student is asked to identify a light curve for a system with eccentric orbits.

Question.Name: Light Curve Locations
Question.Description: The student sees an eclipsing binary system with one orbital position specified and is asked to link that location with a lettered position on the light curve.

Question.Name: Spectroscopic Binaries
Question.Description: Student is shown radial velocity curves for binary systems and asked to identify the orbital period, speed of the CM, speeds of the individual stars about the CM, and mass ratio of the two stars.

Question.Name: CCD Counts
Question.Description: The student is shown a section of a CCD image with number of counts on each pixel labeled and is asked to determine how many come from the star centered somewhere in the image.

Question.Name: Clock Phases
Question.Description: Shown an image of a clock at a certain time and told that 12:00 represents phase 0, the student is asked to determine the phase of one of the hands at a certain hour.

Question.Name: Differential Magnitudes
Question.Description: The student is shown an image of four labeled stars, is given the differential magnitudes between pairs of them, and is asked to determine based on those values which are most likely variable.

Question.Name: Magnitude vs. Time
Question.Description: The student is asked to differentiate between the periodic light curve patterns for RR Lyrae stars and Cepheids, and then he is asked to determine the length of their periods from a graph.

Question.Name: Strobe
Question.Description: The student is told that a wheel with one spoke rotates with a certain period, and a strobe camera takes a short exposure with a different period, and he is asked to determine the direction of the wheel's apparent motion from the strobe images as well as its apparent period.

Question.Name: Period From Data
Question.Description: Given a graph with only a few data points and a timeline, the student is asked to estimate the period they represent.

Question.Name: Telescope Search
Question.Description: The student is shown an HR Diagram with four spots for variable stars labeled and is asked to determine, under the assumption that each is equally abundant through space, which would be most/least likely to be found.

Question.Name: Cepheid Flow Chart
Question.Description: The student is shown a flow chart for steps taken to measure the distance to a Cepheid variable star (measuring the period, apparent magnitude, inferring an absolute magnitude, inferring a distance) and is asked to point out any inconsistencies in the chart.

Question.Name: HR Evolutionary Track
Question.Description: The student is shown an HR diagram and is asked to determine what it represents (motion, evolution, characteristics).

Question.Name: Distance to Cepheids
Question.Description: Given a graph of a Cepheid's periodic light curve and a graph showing the relationship between period and absolute magnitude for Cepheids, the student is asked to deduce the object's distance.

Question.Name: Radial Velocity Curve Amplitude
Question.Description: The student is shown an animation of a binary system and asked to identify the direction of the observer whose radial velocity curves will have the maximum amplitude.

Question.Name: Stars of Albireo
Question.Description: Students are asked to describe the characteristics of the stars of Albireo based upon appearrence.

Question.Name: Sketching Curves
Question.Description: Students are asked to describe the characteristics of the stars of Albireo based upon appearrence.

Question.Name: HR Evolutionary Track
Question.Description: The student is shown an HR diagram and is asked to determine what it represents (motion, evolution, characteristics).

Question.Name: HR Motion
Question.Description: The student is shown an HR diagram and is asked to determine changes in luminosity and temperature for different branches (red giant, horizontal, asymptotic giant).

Question.Name: HR Movement
Question.Description: Shown various arrows pointing along an HR diagram indicating movement of a star on the diagram, the student is asked to determine which descriptions correctly correspond to the directions indicated (nuclear fuel depletion, renewed fusion of a different element).

Question.Name: Core Stages 1
Question.Description: The student is shown various pictures of reactions in stellar cores and is asked to match one with the position indicated on an adjacent HR diagram.

Question.Name: Core Stages 2
Question.Description: The student is shown one picture of a stellar core composition and is asked to find the position it indicates on an adjacent HR diagram.

Question.Name: Sun Stages
Question.Description: The student is shown a timeline of stellar evolution going through the various stages (protostar, main sequence, red/yellow giant, planetary nebula, white dwarf) for a sunlike star and is asked various question regarding the production of elements in various stages or the timespan spent in those stages.

Question.Name: High Mass Star
Question.Description: The student is given a list of properties comparing high mass stars to lower mass stars (position on the main sequence, elements produced, lifetime) and is asked to determine which are applicable.

Question.Name: Main Sequence Lifetimes
Question.Description: The student is shown four points on an HR diagram, and is asked to determine which has the longest/shortest lifetime on the main sequence.

Question.Name: Carbon Stars
Question.Description: The student is asked why certain stars on the asymptotic giant branch show strong carbon lines (carbon stars) in their spectra (dredge up).

Question.Name: Giant Abundance
Question.Description: The student is asked what the ratio of the number of 1 solar mass giant stars to 1 solar mass main sequence stars would be (based on time spent in the stages, temperature, radius, or metallicity).

Question.Name: Cluster Turnoff Points
Question.Description: Given the turnoff points for various clusters on an HR diagram, the student is asked which is the oldest and which the youngest.

Question.Name: Relative Sizes
Question.Description: The student is asked to compare sizes of black holes, white dwarfs, neutron stars, and main sequence stars of various masses.

Question.Name: Planetary Nebula Metals
Question.Description: The student is asked which types of metals end up enriching the interstellar medium after a planetary nebula forms (carbon, nitrogen, oxygen).

Question.Name: Planetary Nebula Spectra
Question.Description: The student is asked whether the spectrum from a planetary nebula is an emission, absorption, or continuous spectrum.

Question.Name: Planetary Nebula Lifetime
