Question.Description: Given that only some 1500 planetary nebulae are known, the student is asked what this indicates about a planetary nebula's lifespan/brightness.

Question.Name: Pulsars
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose which animation of a star emitting a pulsar-like beam at various angles would be a pulsar noticeable from Earth.

Question.Name: Pulsar Period Plot
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose which plot correctly represents how a pulsar's period changes over time.

Question.Name: Schwarzschild Radius
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the Schwarzschild radius of a black hole of given mass, knowing the schwarzchild radius of a different black hole of given mass.

Question.Name: Black Hole Plots
Question.Description: Given four plots showing black hole size against mass of the black hole, the student is asked which is appropriate for black holes themselves and for the schwartzchild radius of blackholes.

Question.Name: Spaghettification
Question.Description: Students are asked about the cause for "spaghettification" near a black hole.

Question.Name: Supernova Venn Diagram
Question.Description: The student is asked to place several properties of supernovae into their respective places in a Venn diagram (for Type Ia and Type II); categories are does/doesn't leave a remnant and useful as a standard candle.

Question.Name: Coulomb Barrier
Question.Description: The student is shown various fusion reactions for various elements and is asked how many times greater the given reaction's Coulomb barrier would be compared to the proton-proton cycle.

Question.Name: Mass Transfer
Question.Description: Given a table of four binary star systems with stars of various masses and places on the main sequence (red giant or main sequence), the student is asked which set indicated that mass transfer has occurred.

Question.Name: Most Massive Nuclei
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify the most massive nuclei that will fused in stars of different masses.

Question.Name: Lifetimes from Table
Question.Description: Given a table with spectral type and masses of various stars (some left blank), the student is asked which star with the given properties would have the longest/shortest lifespan.

Question.Name: White Dwarf Radii
Question.Description: Given a plot of radius against mass, the student is asked which line on the plot correctly represents the mass-radius relationship for white dwarfs.

Question.Name: Cool White Dwarfs
Question.Description: The student is asked why no white dwarf has a cooler temperature than WD 0346+246.

Question.Name: Massive Star Concept Map
Question.Description: Shown a concept map of the evolution of a massive star, the student is asked to fill in one of the bubbles.

Question.Name: Size from Light Variations
Question.Description: Students are questioned about the relation between an object's size and the timescale over which it can vary.

Question.Name: Fast Neutron Stars
Question.Description: The student is asked why some neutron stars are seen to be traveling at large velocities (influence of supernovae).

Question.Name: Binary Star End States
Question.Description: Given a binary system with a 1.3 solar mass star and a 1.0 solar mass star, the student is asked which outcome involving white dwarfs and neutron stars are not possible.

Question.Name: Supernova Danger
Question.Description: The student is asked how one would determine the danger of a supernova to Earth, given that supernovae are only threatening nearer than 100 light years away.

Question.Name: Rotation Curve Meaning
Question.Description: Shown the rotation curve of the Milky Way galaxy, the student is asked to determine what a point on that curve represents.

Question.Name: Rotation Curves
Question.Description: The student is asked to match the given rotation curves with various kinds of rotation (galaxy, solar system, pizza, carousel).

Question.Name: Disk and Halo Characteristics
Question.Description: Shown a Venn Diagram of properties of the Milky Way (in the halo and in the disk), the student is asked to place various characteristics (O and B star abundance, metallicity, open or globular cluster quantity).

Question.Name: Orbits of Stars in Halo and Disk
Question.Description: The student is asked to describe the orbits of stars in either the halo or disk (elliptical/circular, coplanar/randomly oriented).

Question.Name: Blackhole Star Orbit
Question.Description: The student is shown the orbit of star SO-19 orbiting the black hole at the center of the galaxy, and is asked to determine where the black hole lies.

Question.Name: Galactic Doppler Shift
Question.Description: Using an animation of stellar rotation about the galactic center compared to the sun's motion, the student is asked to determine whether stars in certain locations would appear redshifted, blueshifted, or unshifted.

Question.Name: Mass-Velocity-Radius Relation
Question.Description: Given the mass formula (M=vr^2/G), the student is asked what can be determined knowing the velocity and radius of a star's orbit in the Milky Way.

Question.Name: Globular Cluster Distribution
Question.Description: Knowing that Harlow Shapely estimated that the center of the galaxy was at the center of the globular cluster distribution, the student is asked to determine where on a diagram showing such a distribution would be the galactic center.

Question.Name: Change in Metals
Question.Description: Given a number of curves of metallicity over time, the student is asked to determine which corresponds to the change in metal content over time for stars in either the halo or the disk.

Question.Name: Cepheid Flow Chart
Question.Description: Given a flowchart of information used to determine the distance of a Cepheid variable, the student is asked to determine if any particular step in the chart in incorrect.

Question.Name: Halo Stars Metallicity
Question.Description: Given that the stars in the galactic halo have low but non-zero metallicity, the student is asked to determine why some halo stars have metal content.

Question.Name: Metallicity
Question.Description: The student is given either the hydrogen and helium content of a star and asked to determine the metallicity, or he is given the hydrogen content and metallicity of a star and asked to determine its helium content.

Question.Name: Appearance
Question.Description: Students are presented with images of galaxies and asked a) which is like the Milky Way and b) which is the Milky Way?

Question.Name: Distance to Cepheids
Question.Description: Given a graph of various Cepheid light curves (Cet, RT Mus, S Nor), the student is asked to use the period and apparent magnitude of the star in combination with a graph of period versus absolute magnitude for Cepheid variables in order to determine the distance to the star.

Question.Name: Metallicity Analogy
Question.Description: Shown a painting and given the definition of 'chromicity', the student is asked to determine the chromicity of a painting given its color histogram.

Question.Name: Dwarf Galaxy Discovery
Question.Description: The student is asked to make a list of possible reasons why the Sagittarius Dwarf Galaxy, which is colliding with the Milky Way, wasn't discovered until 1994.

Keywords.Keyword: A creative question in which students of the future are asked to tell a campfire story about either Hubble ir Shapley.

Question.Name: Galaxy Components
Question.Description: The student is asked which types of galaxies (spiral, elliptical, irregular) have which components (sphere, disk, neither).

Question.Name: Hubble Tuning Fork
Question.Description: The student is asked what use has the Hubble tuning fork diagram (classification by shape, determining evolution, metalicity, age, size).

Question.Name: Galaxy Characteristics
Question.Description: The student is shown a Venn diagram intersecting all three types of galaxies (elliptical, spiral, and irregular) and is asked to determine where certain characteristics would fall in the diagram (brightness, star formation, commanality, age of stars).

Question.Name: Elliptical Galaxy Calculations
Question.Description: The student is asked to use the index for describing elliptical galaxy shapes to determine the ellipticity of various galaxies.

Question.Name: Spiral Galaxy Classification
Question.Description: Shown a graph of nucleus size against degree of spiral arm winding for spiral galaxies, the student is asked to determine where on the graph would fall spiral galaxies of types Sa, Sb, and Sc.

Question.Name: Protogalactic Cloud
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine characteristics of the protogalactic cloud that would form elliptical/spiral galaxies (high/low density/angular momentum).

Question.Name: Galaxy Colors
Question.Description: The student is asked why spiral and irregular galaxies appear white or blue in color and why elliptical galaxies appear red.

Question.Name: Galaxy Collisions
Question.Description: The student is asked to compare the frequency of galaxy collisions today versus in the distant past.

Question.Name: Galaxies in Clusters
Question.Description: The student is asked what a galaxy at the center of a well-populated cluster would be like (spiral, irregular, elliptical).

Question.Name: Stars in Galactic Collisions
Question.Description: Given the ratio of distance between stars to star size, the student is asked what this indicated regarding star formation during galaxy collision.

Question.Name: Possible Merger Outcomes
Question.Description: Given four images of galactic mergers (between elliptical and/or spiral galaxies), the student is asked which image is inconsistent with current galactic merger theory.

Question.Name: Galaxy Abundances
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine what kinds of galaxies would fall in a catalog of galaxies with a certain apparent magnitude or distance (elliptical, spiral, or irregular).

Question.Name: Quasar Logic
Question.Description: Given a chain of logic for quasar spectra (large redshifts->large recessional velocities->great distance->very luminous), the student is asked to determine which steps are governed by which laws (inverse squares, Doppler formula, Hubble's law).

Question.Name: Ratio of Spirals and Ellipticals
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify how the ratio of the number of spiral to elliptical galaxies has changed over time.

Question.Name: Star Formation Rates
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose which graph accurately represents star formation rates in elliptical/spiral/irregular galaxies.

Question.Name: Spiral Arms
Question.Description: Shown an animation of linear masses of material spiraling from differential rotation, the student is asked what this says about the spiral arms of galaxies.

Question.Name: Globular Cluster Distances
Question.Description: Given what the absolute magnitude is for globular clusters (standard candles) in galaxies, the student is asked to determine the distant to a galaxy whose clusters have a given apparent magnitude.

Question.Name: Merger Characteristics
Question.Description: Shown a graph of density of galaxies in a cluster against number of members of that cluster, the student is asked to determine where on the graph the most galactic mergers would occur.

Question.Name: Centerless Expansion Models
Question.Description: Shown four images (blowing up a balloon, baking raisin cake, exploding bomb, puddle of water), the student is asked to determine which misrepresents a centerless expansion.

Question.Name: Hubble Constant Statements
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify which statement regarding Hubble's Law is true.

Question.Name: Effects of Expansion
Question.Description: Studnents are questioned about the expansion of the universe not applying to "bound" things.

Question.Name: Hubble's Law
Question.Description: The student is asked to pick from five graphs which represents correctly recessional velocity versus distance for galaxies according to Hubble's Law.

Question.Name: Hubble Constant 1
Question.Description: Shown four images of galaxies with given distances from the Milky Way and their recessional velocities as seen from the Milky Way, the student is asked to determine what the velocities would look like from various vantage points (Hubble's constant).

Question.Name: Hubble Constant 2
Question.Description: Shown four images of galaxies with given distances from the Milky Way and their recessional velocities as seen from the Milky Way, the student is asked to determine what the velocities would look like from various vantage points (Hubble's constant).

Question.Name: Universe Age from the Hubble Diagram
Question.Description: Students are asked to draw conclusions about the age of the universe in several Hubble plots.

Question.Name: Units of the Hubble Constant
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify the dimensions of the Hubble Constant.

Question.Name: Expansion Properties
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine what would determine if the universe would expand forever: normal matter, dark matter, dark energy.

Question.Name: Local Group
Question.Description: This is a description of this question

Question.Name: Hubble Diagram Uncertainties
Question.Description: This is a description of this question

Question.Name: Cosmological Principle
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose from a list in which conditions would the cosmological principle be invalid for our universe.

Question.Name: The Universe from a Distant Galaxy
Question.Description: This is a description of this question

Question.Name: Universe Changes
Question.Description: This is a description of this question

Question.Name: Expansion Rate
Question.Description: This is a description of this question

Question.Name: Composition of the Universe
Question.Description: This is a description of this question

Question.Name: Future of the Universe
Question.Description: Shown a graph with various lines depicting the universe's scale over time for various scenarios, the student is asked to determine which corresponds to an accelerating/open/closed/flat universe, and which represent densities above/below/equal to the critical density.

Question.Name: Solar Nebula Composition 2
Question.Description: This is a description of the question

Question.Name: Formation Temperatures
Question.Description: This is a description of the question

Question.Name: Planet Formation Temperature
Question.Description: This is a description of the question

Question.Name: Planet Densities
Question.Description: This is a description of the question

Question.Name: Differentiation Effects on Density
Question.Description: This is a description of the question

Question.Name: Density Changes Over Time
Question.Description: This is a description of the question

Question.Name: Planet Characteristics
Question.Description: Shown a Venn diagram of characteristics of jovian planets versus those of terrestrial, the student is asked to place various bodies in the various regions on the diagram (masses, densities, orbit, etc.).

Question.Name: Orbits of Planets
Question.Description: Given four images of concentric rings (grooves on a record, stack of hula hoops, a 'space-age mobile', and a Japanese steakhouse onion ring volcano), the student is asked which best represents the formation of the planets in the solar system.

Question.Name: Terrestrial and Jovian Planets
Question.Description: Given a table of information on a newly discovered planet, the student is asked to determine whether it would be classified as a jovian planet or a terrestrial planet.

Question.Name: Cratering Rate
Question.Description: Given a number of curves showing cratering rate over time since the formation of the solar system, the student is asked which is most accurate.

Question.Name: Half-Life 1
Question.Description: Given a certain number of atoms with a given half-life, the student is asked to determine how many would remain after a given time period.

Question.Name: Half-Life 2
Question.Description: Shown a starting image of 64 balloons, the student watches an animation during which the balloons pop, and is asked to determine based on this animation what is the half-life for the balloons.

Question.Name: Mass vs. Distance Graph
Question.Description: Given a plot of mass against distance from the sun, the student is asked to determine where various solar system objects of certain types would be location on this graph (gas giants, ice giants, jovians, terrestrial planets).

Question.Name: Accretion Theories
Question.Description: This is a description of the question

Question.Name: Cleared Neighborhood Statistic
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: ESP Orbit Animation
Question.Description: The student is asked what's wrong with the given animation of a planet orbiting its parent star as seen from above the plane of rotation.

Question.Name: Fireflies
Question.Description: The mayor of Gartham City is using a spotlight to call FireFly Man, and the student is asked whether the image of fireflies floating in the spotlight is an accurate one.

Question.Name: Overview
Question.Description: The student is asked how many extrasolar planets have been discovered up until the time this question was written, and he is asked to determine the expected frequency of finding such planets given the current theory of star formation.

Question.Name: Types of Evidence
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Doppler Sign Convention
Question.Description: Using the equation for the Doppler effect (wavelength and radial velocity), the student is asked to compare a standard wavelength against measured wavelengths in order to determine if the orbiting body has negative/positive radial velocity (a convention) and if it's moving toward or away from the Earth.

Question.Name: ESP Doppler Shift
Question.Description: Shown an animation of a planet and star orbiting their center of mass, the student is asked to determine the wavelength shift (Doppler effect; red shift, blue shift, unshifted) in the star's spectrum for different positions in its and in the planet's orbit, relative to Earth.

Question.Name: Radial Velocity Curve
Question.Description: Shown an animation of a planet and star orbiting their center of mass, the student is asked to determine which point on a corresponding radial velocity curve of the system corresponds to the position of the star/planet in the orbit from the Earth's vantage point.

Question.Name: Amp and Period
Question.Description: The student is asked to choose between four radial velocity curves of stars with one companion planet with an edge-on orbit which has the largest/smallest amplitude/period.

Question.Name: Radial Velocity Curve Shift
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Spectral Line Shifts
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Radial Velocity Characteristics
Question.Description: Given a plot of distance from the parent star against mass of the companion planet, the student is asked in what region of the graph would most stars be found using the radial velocity method.

Question.Name: RV Changes 1
Question.Description: The student is shown the radial velocity curve for a star with one companion planet in an edge-on, circular orbit, and is asked to predict how the amplitude of the curve would change with changing mass of the planet/star.

Question.Name: RV Results
Question.Description: The student is asked various questions about the radial velocity method: the bound on the mass of the planet, and the applicability for planets in various configurations/masses/brightnesses of the planet or star.

Question.Name: Transit Detection
Question.Description: Given a radial velocity curve of a planet in an edge-on, circular orbit, the student is asked where on the curve would be the best place to detect the planet using the transit method.

Question.Name: Planets Affecting the Sun
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Kepler Space Telescope
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Pulse Arrival Intervals
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Pulsar Movements
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Inclination 90 degrees
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Density Determination
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Detection Methods Venn Diagram
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Kepler Transit Detection
Question.Description: Students are asked to identify which of several planets of different size of different distance from their star would be easiest for Kepler to detect.

Question.Name: a_vs_e
Question.Description: Students are shown a graph of orbital eccentricity vs semi-major axis for about 100 massive extra solar planets. They are asked to identify how this dataset differs from the Jovian planets in our own solar system.

Question.Name: RV Changes 2
Question.Description: The student is shown the radial velocity curve for a star with one companion planet in an edge-on, circular orbit, and is asked to predict how the amplitude/period of the curve would change with changing mass of the planet/star.

Question.Name: Massive Stars
Question.Description: Students are asked to display an understanding of why if it difficult to detect ESPs around massive stars.

Question.Name: Detection Confirmation
Question.Description: Students are asked about how often RV techniques and transits techniques could be used to verify detections.

Question.Name: Transit Times
Question.Description: Given a graph of brightness versus time for an ESP transit, students are asked to identify which time intervals on the graph correspond to diameters of the star and planet.

Question.Name: Craters and Surface Age 1
Question.Description: Given three different crater maps showing varying degrees of crater intensity, the student is asked which map shows a surface that's uniformly young, uniformly old, or partially resurfaced.

Question.Name: Craters and Surface Age 2
Question.Description: Given various kinds of crater maps showing various degrees of cratering for a surface, the student is asked to determine the ages of the surfaces depicted

Question.Name: Heat of Formation Analogy
Question.Description: The student is shown four basins of water with four attached drains representing the heat of formation of the body and the subsequent heat loss (respectively), and is asked to determine which basin represents which body (Mercury, Earth, Mars, or a small asteroid).

Question.Name: Light Intensity
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the light intensity hitting the surfaces of identical planets are varying distances from the sun.

Question.Name: Earth's Early Atmosphere
Question.Description: The student is asked what happened to the hydrogen, helium, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, ammonia, methane, and oxygen that were present in Earth's primeval atmosphere.

Question.Name: Mercury's Scarps
Question.Description: The student is given a scale and an image of a scarp on the surface of Mercury, and is asked to estimate the length of the scarp.

Question.Name: Planets of Rock and Ice
Question.Description: Given three images displaying different varieties of differentiation, the student is asked to determine which image corresponds to a large or small body of rock and ice.

Question.Name: Length of Mercury Night
Question.Description: Given the period of rotation and revolution of Mercury and aided by an animation, the student is asked to determine how long a night lasts on the surface of Mercury.

Question.Name: Synchronized Rotation
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the resonance of rotation of an object orbiting the sun by watching an animation of a body in synchronus rotation.

Question.Name: Radar and Planet Distance
Question.Description: Told that the distances to planets are determined by bouncing radar pulses off of them, the student is asked to determine a reasonable time-scale for a pulse's return from Mercury at various positions around the sun.

Question.Name: Venus Rotation
Question.Description: Given that the sun rises in the west on the equator of Venus in January and sets in the east in March, the student is asked to determine the speed and direction of Venus' rotation.

Question.Name: Incomplete Concept Map
Question.Description: The student is given a concept map with the concepts Earth's interior, solid inner core, mantle, and crust, and he is asked to add onto this map nodes for convection, liquid inner core, magnetic field, plate, and plate tectonics.

Question.Name: Shepherd Moons
Question.Description: Shown an image of one of Saturn's rings and a shepherd moon, the student is asked to determine (based on the moon's location) what effect the moon has on the distribution of the material in the ring.

Question.Name: Jupiter Themisto Eclipse Seasons
Question.Description: something

Question.Name: Characterisitics of Debris
Question.Description: This question asks students to compare the size and densities of KBOs, Asteroids, Comets, and Meteoroids.

Question.Name: Comet and Asteroid Orbits
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine the shapes of the Oort Cloud, Kuiper Belt, and Asteroid Belt based on the orbits of long and short period comets as well as asteroids.

Question.Name: Debris Classification
Question.Description: Given a table of various parameters (size, density, eccentricity, semi-major axis) for an object, the student is asked to classify it as a meteoroid, asteroid, comet, or Kuiper Belt object.

Question.Name: Proper Motion
Question.Description: This question asks students to compare the proper motion likely displayed by main belt asteroids, KBOs, and stars in a series of images.

Question.Name: Meteors vs. Meteorites
Question.Description: Students are asked to fill in the blanks in a sentence comparing meteoroids, meteors, and meteorites.

Question.Name: Sources of Meteors and Meteorites
Question.Description: Students are asked if most meteors we see in the sky come from a different source than the meteorites that make it to the ground, and what the sources are.

Question.Name: Meteor Shower Location
Question.Description: Shown an image of the Earth in its orbit about the sun, the student is asked in what region of the Earth one would be most likely to see a meteor shower.

Question.Name: Meteor Shower Paths
Question.Description: Student is asked to choose between graphical depictions of a meteor shower's radiant.

Question.Name: Terrestrial Impacts
Question.Description: Student is shown two terrestrial impacts and asked to compare their ages.

Question.Name: Asteroid Families
Question.Description: Student is asked about the likely origin of asteroids that have similar orbital parameters.

Question.Name: Asteroid Resonances
Question.Description: Student is instances of asteroids in resonance with Jupiter and asked to predict where they will be at a later time.

Question.Name: Occultation Conclusions
Question.Description: This question asks students to draw conclusions regarding the presence of atmospheres around Pluto and Charon from stellar occultation observations.

Question.Name: Pluto Stability
Question.Description: Students are asked to explain why Pluto's orbit crosses inside of Neptune's and yet it is not eventually removed from its orbit.

Question.Name: KBO Characteristics
Question.Description: In the different options, students are questions about the distinguishing characteristics of Makemake, Eris, Haumea, and Quaoar.

Question.Name: Graph: Distribution of Comets
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine which graph of orbital inclination against the number of comets accurately represents the distribution of long and short period comets.

Question.Name: Comet Trajectory
Question.Description: The student is shown several images of a comet's path around the sun and is asked to determine which trajectory for the tails is accurate.

Question.Name: Comet Spectra
Question.Description: The student is asked to describe the spectra produced by both the dust and gas tails of a comet.

Question.Name: Asteroid Density
Question.Description: Provided with the density of rock and ice, students are asked to determine the likely composition of an object with a given density.

Question.Name: KBO Resonances
Question.Description: Students are asked to idensity mathematical formulas for the plutino and twotinos. Some options are designed to review using Kepler's third law to related periods and semimajor axes.

Question.Name: Vesta
Question.Description: Told that the comet Vesta was the brightest asteroid of the century in May of 2007, the student is asked which factor did not contribute to this phenomenon (at opposition, at perihelion, large diameter, temperature, or albedo).

Question.Name: Asteroid Impact Probabilities
Question.Description: Student is describe how a golf ball getting closer to the hole is an analogy for an asteroid initially predicted to hit Earth.

Question.Name: Tidally Locked
Question.Description: Students are asked decribe the effect on lunar phases if the Earth-moon system were tidally locked like the Pluto-Charon system.

Question.Name: Sedna's Orbit
Question.Description: Students are presented with a diagram of Sedna's orbit compared to other solar sytem object's and asked to draw conclusions about what astronomer's know about how often an object like Sedna could have been detected and how common they are.

Question.Name: Figure Eight
Question.Description: Students are asked to explain a double lake formation in Canada.

Question.Name: Eta Carinae Binary Evidence
Question.Description: The student is asked to determine from a list which interpretation following the theory that it's a binary system doesn't logically follow from the evidence presented.

Question.Name: Aliens - Fact or Fiction?
Question.Description: The student is asked whether or not he believes in aliens.

Question.Name: Vanessa Williams - Lyrics
Question.Description: The student is given the lyrics by Vanessa Williams: "Sometimes the snow comes down in June, sometimes the sun goes 'round the moon" and is asked under what circumstances these might be true.

Question.Name: Closer Means More
Question.Description: The student is told that a campfire reinforces a scout's idea that 'closer means more' and is asked to come up with more such circumstances.
